The NY Times has a fairly good bio for Judge Roberts.
 
 http://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/21/politics/21nominee.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5094&en=3e6d2bbcdacc8242&hp&ex=1122004800&partner=homepage
 
 One quote in particular struck me:
 
 In his confirmation testimony two years ago, he said that judges should be "ever mindful that they are insulated from democratic pressures precisely because the framers expected them to be discerning law, not shaping policy," and added: "That means that judges should not look to their own personal views or preferences in deciding the cases before them. Their commission is no license to impose their preferences from the bench."
 
 If he holds to that belief than we could do alot worse. Unfortunately his tenure on the bench has been so short that it's hard to say if he meant that, or was just saying what he thought people wanted to hear.

 Yeah, but it's the NYTimes. And it's an editorial. Two things that, together, make a pungent recipe for a nice dish of bias.

Yeah, but it's the NYTimes. And it's an editorial. Two things that, together, make a pungent recipe for a nice dish of bias.

 
 Ha! Talk about a nice dish of bias!
 
 If you had followed the link you would have seen that it wasn't an editorial, but a news article, a biography. Further, if you had read the article you would have seen that it paints a generally positive picture of Roberts.
 
 Or was that supposed to be your point? You don't like Roberts, so anything that speaks well of him is biased? Or does it not matter what the article actually says? If it's in the Times you just automatically disregard it?

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Wanna know more about Roberts?
